Unless you're very hungry, I would skip the overpriced dinner buffet and stick to the "coffee shop," which is open all day and offers a nice range of foods (sri lankan, chinese, and western) with excellent and very attentive service. The breakfast buffet, which is generally included, was also very nice. The spa is also quite pricey for South Asia, but I really enjoyed my treatment there.

Overall I would say this is a superb hotel and would definately recommend it to anyone wanting a relaxing place to stay. The hotel is very clean, the rooms are large and spacious and all the staff are very accomodating. The two infinity pools are lovely and the loungers around them can be moved in to the shade very easily or in to the sun when required. As we went off peak it was incredibly quiet and for 3 days there were only 2 couples around the second pool. The beds are very comfortable and the bathrooms well equipped with large showers and always immaculately clean. Breakfast was always very good with a huge range of food, with omlettes freshly cooked to order. Try the Egg Hoppers! Evening meals were available in the main restaurant generally tended to be from a set menu and were always a high standard - although the Sri Lankans tend to put two different dishes on one course. The Coffee Shop was also very good - you have to try Rice an Curry - a real treat. The Negative Points: On two occassions I sent food back only to have the original food returned........ the first was a chicken burger which I specifically requested to have no cheese on, it was returned with cold chips and the cheese scraped off - absolutely disgusting in my book and they were very apologetic about it. However the waiter spilt an orange juice over another plate of food and said he would get a fresh one, but when he returned the food was still soaked with OJ and underneath the salad there were remnants of the juice, so once again the plate had just been wiped down. I understand they were incredibly quiet but keeping costs down at the expense of the guest is not on. At weekends a lot of Sri Lankans tend to come and stay and the hotel becomes incredibly noisy. If you like early nights and peaceful sleeping I would definately recommend you request a room away from the main pool area. We arrived and were put in to a room facing the main pool and just on walking in the room knew it would be too noisy. We could still clearly hear the Fri and Sat night entertainment in our replacement room and Sat night there was really loud music on until midnight. If you value some peace ask for rooms at the far ends of the hotel. A word of warning regarding the beach hawkers...... unfortunately we had a bad experience with Emile De Silva, we arranged a couple of trips and an evening meal at the Sunshine Restaurant. Whilst the trips were 'ok' I felt crowded by having him, a driver and someone else join us (a trick for getting more money out of us by asking for bigger tips), they rushed us around the nice places and didn't really give us any space and didn't deliver on the glass bottomed boat, whilst still wanting the same money. The evening meal also never materialised with 2 different excuses given and then making us walk miles down the beach to another location which was actually on the road. We lost 1000 rupees as we refused to go as they had not told us earlier in the day there was a problem. Otherwise the other people on the beach were great, the ladies selling the 'sari's' were great fun and whilst they did try and call us over all the time they were lovely. Whilst the negative points above need to be considered, please don't let it put you off. The hotel was wonderful and all the staff would fall over themselves to help. It certainly looks by far the most superior hotel on that coastline. We have certainly agreed we will be returning in 2 years time. Tourism in Sri Lanka is desperately needed and when you spend your money you are treated like Kings. Tip: Take a trip to Unawatuna - a stunning little beach outside Galle which was charming and filled with the locals.

We needed a total escape holiday with complete relaxation and once we got to the Heritance Ahungalla that's exactly what we got. From the moment we arrived, all departments of staff were nothing less than friendly, courteous and helpful, checking our needs were being met at all times, even the boys sweeping the sand/ground maintenance would look up and smile and say hello as you passed by. We had standard rooms booked, a quick email to the hotel before departure to ask for rooms next to each other as we were taking our teenage daughter, prompted an immediate response to assure us that our requirements would be met. The rooms once we got there were next to each other as promised, in a prime location next to the Residents Pool and of an excellent standard. Rooms were attended to twice daily with clean linen and towels. Air conditioning silent. There were always sunbeds available with cushions and plenty of towels, once you'd been by the pool a day, the pool attendant knew how many cushions and towels to bring the next day along with an umbrella and they would be set up ready for you with a smile and a wave from the pool guy! The food was excellent, with choices from The Mustard Cafe, The Jute Restaurant, Fine Dining, the Mirror Bar or room service (which was the most prompt I have ever had - 15 mins!!) it was easy to have completely different things every night. True Sri Lankan food can be very spicy but there was plenty of other choice and on buffet night when they cook the food in front of you, you can opt for no chilli at all should you wish! although personally if you can't take a bit of heat in your food - I wouldn't bother even going to Sri Lanka - you would miss out on so much of the whole experience. Service again was excellent. The pools were gorgeous, beautifully clean although leaves and flowers blew in during the day, the pool guy's fished them out. The hotel can get busy at weekend with Locals coming for the day but there is a designated Residents Pool Only that remains quiet. There are plenty of activities too if you are so inclined, our teenagers found plenty to do. Table tennis, badminton, tennis, horse riding, beach or water volleyball, etc etc. We only had to pay extra for the horse riding. There was entertainment on most nights but depending on where your room was, you might not even have realised it! It was easy to go out for quick trip to the next town in a Tuk Tuk with careful negotiatin of price with the drivers hovering round the gate. You need to be firm though or they get carried away with ideas and want to take you places! They are so proud to show you their country. This hotel is quite a long way from any of the other known tourist sites and would require a long journey (due to the roads not the distance) and overnight stay. We didn't attempt this on this visit but probably will next time. I needed two visits to the spa as one wasn't enough!! lovely lovely lovely! The beach was beautiful but as it was monsoon season the sea was way too rough to swim in, however great fun can be had paddling - i wouldn't take small children in though as some of the waves were unexpectedly deep, the undertow was very strong, a small child could very easily get knocked over and dragged out before you''ve time to react. We didn't suffer with much rain though, what came was mostly at night. We had some cloud but it was a relief in between the searing heat and the little rain showers didn't affect you if you were in the pool - the pools guys just folded up the cushions with your towel/book/sunglasses inside while it passed! There was a constant breeze though which was lovely , if you go out of monsoon season, there is no wind, the sea is apparently like a millpond! Transfer fom Colombo, while only 74km, took over 3 hours due to the lack of roads in Sri Lanka, everybody is filtered onto the same few. The roads are in excellent repair, just very full. This is the perfect time to soak up the atmosphere of Sri Lanka though and the journey passed easily enough (both ways) in an airconditioned vehicle. If you read reviews from some of the other hotels along this route, the A2/Galle Road, you will notice most people mention the railway runs alongside it and can cause distubances at 6am in some cases! This is not the case here as the main road is on the 'sea' side of the line which veers inland a bit in this area. The hotel gates once closed seem to be holding this quiet little paradise inside. No main road traffic or railway noise can be heard in the hotel grounds at any time. Perfectly peaceful! We had the most amazing time at this hotel - there were 3 weddings too which was lovely to watch with the visiting elephant! It was exactly the kind of holiday we needed, a lovely hotel with wonderful staff - it truly was paradise.

What a great place to relax and recharge the batteries. This hotel is in a fabulous setting with nice grounds. The rooms were a good size with everything you need. Great pool and beachside. The food was good, however the main restaraunt is very dark. Not the best atmosphere. Can recommend the spa facilities, my wife and I loved it. Say hello to Luxman (Lucky), The head pool barman, who will happily look after all your needs from exotic cocktails to lunch time snacks at the pool bar. Overall a great place to stay. A quality hotel from the Aitken Spence group.

Lovely hotel. On beautiful beach. Recommended by our guide - we were booked in to the Lighthouse but our guide - Karnal De Silva see karnadesilva.com - suggested this would be better since it actually had access directly onto a lovely beach. It was far better. Two great pools. Lovely staff. Clean. Although no restaurants nearby, the hotel restaurants are not at all overpriced. Simply lovely.

We read all of the guide books and surfed the net before plumping for this hotel having spent the first night at the tired and desperately in need of a refurb Bentota beach resort , great pool sweaty sheets.... only 45 minutes from Galle, which is only worth a day trip any way if you ask me.... If you are looking for a beach side paradise with a modern room with quiet aircon and sliding doors onto a pool that is pure bliss for midnight swims then this cant be faulted. Food is great, plenty of options and places to eat, your room, the terrace, cafe or fine dining. Tennis, Snooker and yoga, not in that order.... We stayed in 5 hotels from Kandy, Nuwara, Dambulla and here. this was the best value and the most excellent. service was fab. Although all heritance hotels are good the one at Dambulla is triple the price for example; for food and beverages. Stay at the earls regeency or mahawali reach in kandy> tea plantation or St andrews in Nuwara Elya and the kandalama in Dambulla, expensive but a truely natural experience, like having a safari in your room! monkeys on the balcony, bats in the corridors and an infinty pool overlooking the wilderness. Snakes and lizards every where, in a nice way! oh and if you want golf the only place to play is the sublime course near Kandy at victoria. a real gem. Enjoy

I won't add much to all that's been said already. This is a really lovely hotel and we would have been very sad to leave had we not been going on to The Maldives. We spent two weeks in a luxury room but the de-luxe rooms were very nice also. Maybe the standard rooms don't have such a great aspect in some cases but that is normal in ANY hotel. I've stayed in 5 star hotels in various parts of the world and this is probably a four-star by U.K standards but it's superb. So relaxing. I want to say that we went with Rassi [ on the beach ] on a half-day trip by tuk-tuk to the River Safari and the moonstone mine and a garden. It was great fun and very cheap and safe. He's a nice guy and so is Silva [ older man with an umbrella,moustache and hat ] also on the beach. I have Rassi's mobile number if you want it. There are a lot of de Silvas in Sri Lanka, it's of Portugeuse origin but the guide who is mentioned frequently on this site is Rammuni de Silva . We had a wonderful two night tour to Kandy in his very comfy people mover [ lovely reclining seats]. His driver is superb and anything we wanted to do was arranged plus some really nice thoughtful touches. We stopped to eat at authentic 'restaurants' and the food was delicious. Rammuni arranged for us to release turtles, wash elephants and lots more.He even got us cut-price seats at the magnificent perahera. He has so many contacts everywhere and is also good company. I heartily recommend him and have his contact details so just email me. I wish you a wonderful trip.We had a whale of a time [ or should I say turtle].

I stayed at the Heritance for 3 weeks and I can only praise the Management and all the staff as they are all exceptional people, always smiling and nothing is too much. They really do take care of you and they take great pride in the hotel and there work. The food is outstanding and with great thought and preparation. I would highly recommend a stay at the Heritance. I never thought I would experience the emotions I did on leaving. A very exceptional place and very exceptional staff.

We travelled to this hotel with Kuoni travel under the idea that it was a 5* luxury hotel. This hotel had all the potential of a good 4* hotel. The beech was amazing the staff were amazing, however there always seemed to be something missing and not quality about the hotel. We stayed at this hotel for 7 nights having travelled around the island for 4-5 days. The poolside service was very good with staff being extremely friendly and chatty. The animator was also a healthy addition to the hotel encouraging water polo and other activates throughout the day. The pool bar offered a nice little lunchtime snack menu however every meal was with French fries and wasnâ€™t the best quality. We recommend sprite as it was half the price of coke or diet coke. The sprite was around 70p and coke was Â£1.50 for a can. There was also a service charge on each bill so there was no need for tipping and carrying cash as it could all be charged to the room The evening food in the main restaurant under a set menu was very average and was trying to be to clever for its own good. Not much variety if you were a fussy eater and didnâ€™t like fish. The al a carte restaurant (or coffee shop) offered a welcome opportunity to get a square meal. This was available with a 10% discount to half and full board customers. when the hotel got busy at the weekend however the restaurant came alive with a huge Mexican and bbq buffet on the Friday and Saturday nights. The breakfasts were also very good with every possible breakfast such as omelettes and waffles. However, when the weekend did arrive the hotel filled with hundreds of locals. This wasnt a problem until the quiet pool became a holiday at butlans with kids screaming and weeing into the pool. The locals were then extremely rude to the friendly staff making the stay extremely uncomfortable as you had to witness this behaviour. The staff were being shouted at and fingers clicked at with no manners. It was clear that the other guests felt the same through conversations in the lobby. The evening buffet at the weekend although it had good food resembled a school canteen. At 9 oclock families were bringing there young screaming children to dinner. Those children who were not dead on there feet at this time were runing around bumping in to the staff and other guests. This un civilised behaviour caused some couples to leave in disgust. The room was very good although we were continually being pested by staff asking if the room was ok. Also the wiring of the room was questionable with switches for different lights being in the wrong place. The beech was a no go area also as you were trying to have a romantic walk along the beech and were surrounded by peopel trying to sell you trips and clothing. Even when you were trying to sun bathe there was a constant noise coming from the beech of people trying to grab your attention. As a result of this I would not recommend this hotel to anyone I liked. I will also be informing Kuoni of the hotel at the weekend.

What can I say about The Heritance that hasn't already been said except don't take my word for it, just go and sample it yourself. Everything, - rooms, staff, food, location - is absolutely fantastic and I'll certainly return. We've stayed previously in Sri Lanka at The Taj Exotica and although that was nice The Heritance has the edge. We stayed in room 353, which had superb uninterrupted views over the quiet infinity pool and the ocean. It had everything we needed and was kept beautifully clean by the room boys. Excellent value for money was dining in the Jute Restaurant and although the chef did provide two main courses on one plate, if you asked for just one meat they happilly provided it. Breakfast was again wonderful - even bacon and sausages were cooked to order, not left on a hot plate for goodness how long. The only thing I would disagree with other reviewers is the hassle from the beach sellers. They really are no problem at all and, let's face it, spending a few rupees on a sarong is hardly going to break the bank but gives a much needed income to people desperately in need of such. Silva, who patrols the beach, knows everything you need to know and is the loveliest person you could ever wish to meet - so don't be afraid to stop and have a chat with him, you'll be pleasantly surprised, believe me. Don't forget, you're in Sri Lanka and the people are honest and there to serve you. There's also a lovely shack at the end of the beach called the Sunshine Restaurant (its original building, which was beautiful, was unfortunately destroyed in the tsunami) and if you want an excellent cheap lunch time or evening meal then go there. The fish is freshly caught that day, it's beautifully presented and tastes delicious. It;s also spotless. Anyone looking for a good guide should contact D. Karnal de Silva ([--] - tel. [--]). He was recommended by a number of people and we arranged for him and his driver, Sampath to take us from the airport to the Heritance. So impressed were we by his knowledge, excellent English and his driver's safe driving that we booked him to take us to Yala, a three day trip which was the most enlightening trip we have ever had. I can highly recommend him and you will, I am sjure, be every bit as delighted as we were to meet him,. In conclusion, go to The Heritance, enjoy it every much as we did and, of course, Sri Lanka, a beautiful country.

I stayed at heritance on 4th June with my spouse for our honeymoon. i knew its going to be a nice stay and it was indeed nicer than i expected. Location is fantastic. View is heavenly. Staff is soo nice and friendly. SARA was exceptional---Hi Sara!!! Food is good and the room was clean and spaceious. my room was room number 207-Delux, will go back there again soon. simply we are happy and cherish every moment we spent in Heritance.

Just back from amaizing and relaxing trip from Sri Lanka. (4-12.Jun) Positive: exellent service, outstanding food and choice, great value, clean ,frendly staff, great facilties (gym, two outdoor pools, jacuzi, game rooms, libary, internet, two bars, night club, two shops, bussines center, SPA). If you travel by BB package its great to dining in restorans(cheap, around Â£10) , drinks in the bar Â£ 4,50 and beer Â£ 2. It is amaizing hotel. Negative: locals around you on the beach, sundflys, some jelly-fish (but this is nothing to do with hotel) Perfect place and destination for getting away from everything. Ideal for couples and singles. This is not destination who wants active nightlife, animators, screaming childern,lots of tourists and entertaiment, shopping and etc. Recomendation: if you are sensitive person...don't step out from hotel, because locals are very active for selling everything . I guess this is affect after very low tourism level in country. Im surprised, because its great holiday destination. If you decide to travel around, go for two day trip to Kandy, tea plantations, factory and waterfalls...its worth. Buy individual trips from local (sertificated) travel agents, Because holiday providers sale double price for same thing. Two day trip pp around Â£70(incl tickets, car, driver, petrol, guide) plus hotel expensses.(My choice was Thilanka in Kandy, because great value and location, but I recommend stay in Tea Factory or Earls Regency) You can choice and book you hotel or ask to do the guide. Make sure where ever you go, keep in pocket tips, because this system are in all places. Sometimes you can feel uncomfortable. I spent almost Â£40 in thistradition for 7 days.(You can keep in walet 100 rupies notes and this is ok for everything)

Ok so after arriving from a long 11/12 Hour flight from UK the 3 hour transfer to the hotel was not an experience I was looking forward to the traffic was very bad and seemed to take a life time. We had our own private car transfer and I would advise anyone staying to do the same to make the journey more bareable. Upon arrival it was evident the journey had been well worth it the architecture and landscape is truely breath taking. We recieved a warm friendly welcome and was wisked off to the bar for a welcome drink while our luggage was taken to our room. We were shown to our room and the staff member talked us through how to use the air con and the facilities available. As soon as the staff member left my partner and I burst out laughing as we couldn't believe how lucky we were. The room was amazing with stunning Ocean views and the main infinity pool from our balcony. The room is finished to a very high standard, immaculatley clean. Well stocked mini bar (not complimentary), fridge, air con and cieling fan, safe, plenty of storage for clothes, TV, Phone, complimentary water (replenished daily) and a welcome cake. The bathroom had ample towels which were changed twice daily (bare this in mind if you like us to have a nap in the early eve before dinner to put you do not disturb sign on the door so they dont disturb you while your sleeping) complimentary toiletries -shampoo, shower gel and body lotion. Our room had a huge rain shower (room for 2 or even 3 people hehe) I noted there was also a hair dryer but can't say either of us used it. Food-Breakfast was the biggest breakfast buffet I have ever seen it was nice to be able to to sample a Sri Lankan breakfast but no fear if thats not your thing there is much more a wide range of breads, cakes and pasteries, cold meats, cheese, salad, everything for a cooked English breakfast and chefs cooking omelettes, waffles, pancakes and fresh fruit/juice theatre style. (we never felt the need to eat lunch after that lot) We ate dinner in the Mustard Coffee shop on the first night the Lobster was very nice! We had dinner in the main Jute retaurant restaurant for the rest of our stay which was a set menu most evenings about 7 courses, canape, 3 starters usually small bite size of each (served at same time) 2 soups (small cups served at same time) a sorbet then you had a choice of mains which was usually a meat dish a fish/seafood dish and vegetarian option you then had a choice of desserts followed by fresh Ceylon tea or coffee they also had 2 BBQ themed evenings during our stay spoilt for choice for meats and fresh seafoods salads and desserts other hot non BBQ dishes were also available on the buffet such as currys and pasta dishes the cost was 2500 rupees (per person for both the set dinner and BBQ roughly Â£13) which we thought was really good value. The food was always excecuted and presented extremley well although maybe one or two too many components on a plate at the same time (but this is probably my chefy foodie head on) each component tasted great and thats what matters. Drinks- we stuck to drinking the local 'lion' beer for most of our trip (served with a glass that had been stored in the freezer to ensure its stayes nice and cold which was a nice touch) which was 320 rupees (Â£1.70 a pint size bottle) we was shown an extensive wine list that had lots of famliar names I think the cheapest started around Â£12. We drunk our way through the cocktail menu on the last night all very nice particularly their own Heritance cocktail (cant remember exact name i had hade a few by then) made with the local Arak and all the classics are also available all 800 rupees (roughly Â£4.50) we was treated to complimentary canapes and homemade crisps as we enjoyed our drinks service at the bar and restaurant was always great. Facilities - 2 Huge Infinity pools we was lucky the hotel was not busy the only people in them most days the pool attendents were very friendly and sufficent, i noted a tennis court, volly ball net, snooker room, games room although didn't use them so not sure if they have the equipment or you need to bring your own? There internet access in the Library on the second floor it was just over Â£1 for an hour you have to get a card from the reception. Theres a night club on site we popped in briefly but as the hotel was quiet we was the only people in there and wasn't quite the same raving on ya own haha. Music from the club was well contained so not fear of being woken up by music in your room. There is a Spa but was a bit to pricey for us. There is a well equiped gym that is free to guests. We took a tuk tuk (300 rupees roughly Â£1.60 return) down the road to the turtle hatchery 1000 rupees PP entrance donation (Â£5.50) we went around 3pm we was advised the best time to go is around 5/6pm you might then be able to takes some turtles back to the sea (we didnt want wait around that long) still an enjoyable experience either way. The weather was perfect (June 4th-12th 2009) cloudy most days but hot (hot enough to get a tan or burnt in my case) with a nice sea breeze the odd down pour usually in the afternoon but it stops and dry out again real quick didnt bother us at all the sea unfortunately was to rough for a propper swim but was ok for a paddle my partner also go a mild sting from a jelly fish so that put us off going in again. As other people have said in their reviews hawkers (lookie lookie men/woman) are a real hassel on the beach and surrounding area we walked to the local shop to try and buy Cigarettes (you cant bring any in duty free without paying goverment tax) and we were swamped with people trying to talk to us takes us places make us go to shops following us it was a bit overwhelming and i didn't feel particularly safe having so many people around me we didnt leave the hotel on foot again after that. Also many a quiet morning walk on the beach would be spoilt I saw one couple get surrounded by 8 people this is something the resort have no control other however they do have security guards on the beach preventing them entering so no hassel in the resort complex. So an amazing stay! Definatley want to go back.

We have lived in Sri Lanka for a while; hence choosing it for a holiday seemed so perfect. We had only one objective on this holiday- to soak in as much of Sri Lanka as we could â€“ in terms of Sun, sand and Sambol (a fiery chutney made in Sri Lanka) since we are big Sri Lankan foodies. We had heard of Heritance through some friends and also looked it up on the Internet and we decided to try it out. We reached Heritance late afternoon after spending a day in Colombo with friends. As soon as we reached the place, we knew we had made the right choice. Upon entering, we saw a vast expanse of the pool shaded by the beautiful and fragrant frangipani trees and the sea loomed in the horizon beyond.. It was a perfect setting. The Hotel was originally designed by the renowned architect Geoffrey Bawa and is large, airy with trees everywhere. The decor is contemporary yet elegant. Although all the interiors are not completely Bawa, its overall pleasing. The trees and the landscape are beautiful to look. It adds a sense of calmness to the ambience. The hotel is quite spacious and there was a fair amount of walking to do within the corridors but we didnâ€™t mind that at all. We were swiftly taken to our room, we chose a suite.. We wanted a relaxed holiday â€¦ we were staying for 6 nights... we wanted a home away from home The suite was large, spacious and faced another pool and the Indian Ocean. The hotel boasts of 2 main restaurants, a gym, a bar, a fine dinning, pool table and games, library, 2 pools, tennis, cycling and a nice spaâ€¦something for everyone!! We spent the next 6 days next to the pool in a wonderful reclined position eating, drinking and swimming at intervals. Although the hotel was quite full at that time, the staff managed everyone very nicely. The queues were never long, the food was always ample and the staff was ready to serve with a smile. The food was always a choice between Sri Lankan and continental. Since we love Sri Lankan food, it suited us perfectly. The Breakfast was a very good buffet with loads of salads, continental, Sri Lankan and even Indian on certain days. The food overall was plenty and marvelous. The hotel staff was exceptional. In fact if you were traveling with children, I would recommend it strongly. The hotel staff was very generous and helpful with our 2.8 year old and whipped up new dishes only for her and offered it free of charge.. Everyone was very warm and very helpful. The hotel arranged cultural programs but we didnâ€™t see any, as we were busy relaxing if that makes any sense. But I did try the water aerobics organized every morning and I have to admit, I loved it!! I also tried the spa and found it very satisfactory. The thing I loved the most about this hotel was the area around the pool, I would sip my drink under the beautiful frangipani and watch the sun go downâ€¦ the evenings were just exceptionally lovely. The holiday overall was everything we could hope for and more. As I said earlier we wanted to soak in as much of the Sun, sand and sambol as we could manage and I think we did. The Holiday had been â€¦ wellâ€¦ Simply Sri Lankan..

Our stay at the Heritance was memorable. This is a fantastically designed hotel by Sri Lanka's legendary architect Geoffery Bawa. In keeping with his style, the hotel is open to the elements - there is an uninterrupted vista of the sea from the vast, uncluttered lobby with sea breeze blowing in at all times... when the breeze is a little rough, of course, papers, hair, clothes - all go flying up, up and away! The rooms were spacious with views of the sea and well appointed with all mod cons. Two large swimming pools meant you never had to fight for space. The staff was extremely courteous and attentive. Food was uniformly good. The hotel is also a good take off point for Galle and other Southern destinations. LOVED the place and have every intention of returning.

Having read some fantastic reviews of this hotel, we arrived with high expectations. Twice prior to arrival we had reqested a room with a sea view and a double bed. On arrival however we were asked if we wanted to upgrade before even seeing the room, therefore, it came as no suprise that we had neither a sea view nor a double bed as requested. Now I appreciate the hotel was very busy over the Sri Lankan New Year however we had booked well in advance and were assured that within two days we would be moved, which did not materialise despite constant pleas, until day 7 of 10! Agreed the hotel was very clean and in a fantastic location, however, if you are looking for something intimate and romantic this is not the place for you. The beach is beautiful though the hawkers provide little peace and are a constant menace and not to be trusted, given the stories we heard from trusted locals inland.

I'm easily intimidated by 'posh' places but despite this being the classiest hotel I've seen- decor and architecture superb- it was relaxed and friendly. Staff were quietly efficient and helpful but equally happy to chat, or join in ping-pong etc. Pools huge, clean, stunning.Food wonderful-breakfast was incredible- included local dishes as well as everything the fussiest eater could want. Award winning chef knows his stuff. Don't worry about the tuktuk / beach touts- just be friendly but firm if you don't want a tour/tuktuk ride/guide/sarong etc. Anyway you can get better trp deals with them than the (admittedly extortionate) prices the hotel charges. Our favourite 'guide' was N.Wilma de Silva [--]- very cheery chap and good fun. Hotel was near deserted towards end of our 10 day stay as it was v hot- near monsoon. But apparently monsoon rains are intermittent- might consider going there then. Do support the local businesses as they're still building up after the tsunami-shack at the end of the beach serves excellent freshly fished prawns/lobster; new souvenir shop about 1km from hotel is great- the owner came to UK & worked as a cleaner in Woollies for years to build up capital- great bloke. Great holiday of a lifetime. Well worth the money (but we did have a great deal through thomas cook).

We visited Heritence Ahungalle for 2 nights in mid-April 2009. This was our second trip to the property having visited 5 years ago on our last trip to SL. Booked directly through the hotel website after comparing other similar properties such as Taj Exotica Bentota, The Fortress, Galle Fort Hotel and Eden Resort. Chose the Heritence given we had a wonderful stay 5 years ago. I wrote to the hotel inquiring about rates and was promised a free upgrade to a luxury room given that I was a returning guest. The hotel also stated that the property has been completely refurbished hence the drastic increase in price. When I got to the Heritence, I was told I would be given a deluxe room (the most basic room). I advised that I was promised a free upgrade to which I was told that they cannot honour this promise. They then advised that I could have an upgrade to a luxury room for an additional cost of Rs. 10,000 (US$86) per night. Given the higher cost I declined the upgrade and was quite disappointed. I had also requested a cot for my infant son when the booking was made. When I got to the hotel I was told that all the cots were in use. I complained to the General Manager who promised to look into it and get back to me, which he never did. We could not notice the refurbishments made to the property. The room we had looked very similar to the room we had five years ago as did the common areas. The property itself is beautifully maintained and is set on a stunning section of beach in SL. The main infinity pool and lobby area are very beautiful. The food is exceptional with a wide variety of choice all of which are of a very high level of quality. We visited this hotel during the Sri Lankan New Year and the hotel was full of local guests. We were blown away by the property and service on our last visit and were disappointed in the level of service during this trip (the GM has changed once during the past 5 years). I would say that we did have a good time and enjoyed the pool but would not likely return on our next trip to SL given they did not follow through on their promises.

We stayed here for a week before moving onto the Maldives for our honeymoon. The journey to the hotel was long, but the driver was fine and pointed out sights when we passed them. Pulling into the hotel we were certainly impressed, the reception is spacious, the infinity pool is certainly a show stopper. The staff were couterous and knew that we would be tired so they processed us quickly and efficiently. The room of at the hotel was lovely, we didn't have a bath and that would be the only thing we missed... however saying that a bath is not essential and the shower was powerful and was more like a wet room :) The staff were so considerate and they were so efficient. They jumped to your every need and nothing was too much. We were half board, and the prices I would say was a little more than I anticipated for Sri Lanka however I would not say it was expensive. The food itself was yummy... at the buffet there was much variety, the lunch menu at the pool did gorgeous sandwiches, and the curries in the resturant was lovely... never tasted such gorgeous curries before! The beach was lovely, just there was sellars on the beach but they didn't bother us. We just said no and they left us alone. I would not say they interfered with the relaxed atmosphere at the hotel. We went to Sri Lanka to see Sri Lanka before we would have 10 nights of pure relaxation in the Maldives... this hotel is not ideal for touring or if you want to see the sights. Therefore we decided to do a two day tour and then extended that to a three days so we didn't have to do the 4 hour drive back to the hotel to then have to do the 4 hour journey the next day to go back to the airport. We went and saw Sigira... very impressive... and certainly worth a visit, Kandy - we saw the Kandian dancers... and saw the palace.... so beautiful and highly recommended. We Also saw the elephant orphange and the driver under our request took us to a elephant ride in front of Sigira. The sights of seeing the castle in the back ground whilst on an elephant is a moment I will never forget. I can't fault this hotel... the staff were lovely and the hotel itself was beautiful. If you have done a tour of sri lanka and want a hotel for the end of the tour I would recommend this hotel hands down, if you want a hotel that you just sunbathe and unwind then this is it... however if you want to tour sri lanka and visit Kandy, Sigiria or Galle then this hotel is too far out really. It takes about 3 hours to get anywhere which if you are there for a week or so and then use the days to do a 6 hour round trip then that is not ideal.

Beautifully designed hotel. An open design so that there is maximum light and air. The pools are lovely and my room had a beautiful sea view. It is however, extremely quiet and quite far from colombo. There is also unfortunately no spa. The food and service were also good.

Just returned from a memorable 10 Night stay at the Heritance. We originally booked a luxury room but were disappointed with the small bathroom and location. As the hotel was full had to spend first night in there but next day upgraded to a de-lux room with bath and shower which was much larger and in a better, quieter location with superb sea view. The room was kept well cleaned and topped up. The pools are warm, clean and were never overcrowded. Particually liked the hotel location on a long sandy beach with the warm sea water and whilst the sea was too rough for proper swimming some days, it was fine for a splash around in the waves, on a couple of days I hired a body board (200 rupees) which was fun. We also enjoyed many early morning or late afternoon â€˜womblesâ€™ along the waters edge sometimes accompanied by a local dog or two who kept us amused chasing birds and crabs. We stayed on half board, the breakfast and evening buffets were excellent with a good choice of both local and international food. Some evenings the buffet menu was themed with a grill night, chinese or local theme which gave a good variety. We had a few lunches at the hotel which worked out around Â£12 for 2 including drinks, so as advised on the forum, full board is not really worth while. There are several other options for dining in the hotel but you only get a 15% discount at those if you are on half board. The staff at the Heritance are helpful, friendly and go out of their way to make you feel welcome and all seem very proud to work there. The beach touts were no worse than other places weâ€™ve visited in Sri Lanka and India but appreciate they can be a problem especially if you have not encountered them before. We generally exchanged some banter and a hand shake with them and unless we wanted to sort a trip out they would leave us alone. We did a couple of riverboat trips with Ajith who we found really helpful. Also went to the Lucky Lanka Spice and Herb Garden (a couple of minutes down the road from the hotel towards Gaulle) where you can get a herbal balm massage for 1500 Rupees, great for aches and creaky joints! We certainly enjoyed our stay here and will return again.

We came from France and loved all the country;We went to heritance Ahnugalla last february with two children 12 and 15; beautiful hotel and very nice staff, but much expensive food and services ; let suggest you search on the beach for Fredi (freditour:; contact is also at [--]), very nice guy who can organize everything for you: food, grilled fish on the beach, trips,diving, transfers...at very good prices and he is a very nice person; we enjoyed a lot staying there during the holiday and made a lot of trips around with him; just ask for Fredi and be sure you have to deal with him....you wont regret it!

Another Aitken Spence hotel, very minimalist, white painted, long corridors with one simple table and mirror. Beautiful approach along a long driveway with open reception and a view of the sea across the infinity pool. The room was average size for a beach hotel but the bathroom was tiny with no bath, just a shower. We had the biggest balcony ever, it ran around the side of the building and had fabulous views of the sea and pool. The staff were fantastic, they couldn't do enough for you, but then the hotel was nowhere near full and they often stood around wanting to do something. The food was excellent but rather expensive. My husband thought he'd paid off the national debt when he got the bill at the end of a weeks holiday. There is nowhere else to go as the hotel stands on its own. There was a beach bar about 100 yards away up the beach for day time use but you had to run the touts and beach boys/girls to get there. I know the hotel have no control over the touts and beach boys but they did spoil the holiday. We couldn't even go for a walk down the beach without someone attaching themselves to us trying to sell us something - coconut, pineapples, hats, sarongs, trips, etc. Would I recommend this hotel to a friend? Yes if they wanted to get away from everything and have a beautiful beach. No if they wanted to be in the heart of things. This hotel is 3.5 hours away from the airport and with a 3 hour check in for international flights we had done a day's work before we even got on the plane. There are no shops to speak of on the road, only a local wine shack to buy Arak and a tiny 'supermarket'. We did feel rather isolated and ended up walking the hotel corridors as there is nowhere to go!

My husband and i stayed here for only 4 nights as part of our very own tour. It seems allot of people stay here for 1 to 2 weeks. The hotel entrance will bring a smile to your face and it really sets out to be luxurious. We opted to upgrade ourselves to a sea view suite and were really impressed with the huge bed, the huge bathroom, the lounge and our own balcony with sunloungers. it was a real treat. Food at the hotel is mainly the buffet option which is very good value for money and the food is also very good. They had a set menu one night which we found to be a little mean on the portions, but maybe we eat allot! Room service is also very very good food. Having stayed at the Kandalama property we found service not to be of as high a quality and it was bit of a nuisance to have to hunt down a pool attendant so you could get a sun lounger. Positives Great location, great view, fantastic suite, lovely food Negatives This of course is personal, but we felt quite strongly about these points, so we have added them ... Other guests at the hotel were buying from the beach hawkers who would shout to get your attention. Why do this, it ruins the serentity for your fellow guests! Dont be so lazy, get out of the resort if you are there for 2 weeks and see some sites!. Plus you wouldnt have a man on the beach with a monkey chained to him so you can have your photo taken! i think if you come here for a package of 1-2 weeks and you enjoy tanning all day and not really seeing Sri Lanka then you will enjoy it here. Had we not upgraded i dont think i would have really liked this hotel. Maybe find something smaller and more intimate

Sri Lanka was one of the places we wanted to include on our vacation as we were highly really excited about viisting this place. We have heard both good and bad about the country.However,looking at the picturesque locations of Sri Lanka gave us the boost to visit the place. We decided to book the hotels on-line which gave us the opportunity to directly deal with the hotel rather than going through a third party. We were assisted with all the questions we had and we got exactly what we were told by the Colombo Head office. Finally after we got all the matters clarified,we proceeded with our on-line reservation by only paying a 25% deposit through our credit card. Heritance Ahungalla was our selection to spend our seven day vacation as it was known as the best five star beach resort in Sri Lanka. The Two and half hour ride on a Sunday morning was ok after a long flight from UK as our driver sent from the hotel was very friendly and helpful. The warm welcome received with a flower garland indeed made you feel welcomed. Just after ten minutes of arrival we were taken to our wonderful Luxury room facing the marvellous Indian Ocean. The friendly staff,the good service,the delicious meals served in various restaurants and the beautiful swimming pool stretched to the lobby indeed made the hotel a place you should be. After spending three days in Ahungalla sunbathing and relaxing we decided to explore more of the country by visiting the hotel's sister hotels in Nuwara Eliya and Kandy. We followed the same way of booking these hotel also through the web since we were expecting the same good service from the other hotels as well. We decided to book two nights in Tea Factory,Nuwara Eliya and two nights in Earl's Regency,Kandy to stop over to and from our drive to Tea Factory. Each and every hotel had its unique beauty and excellent service to be extended to different travellers. Learning the process of tea making,early morning walks around the beautiful garden, unique dinning experience on the railway carriage and relaxing treatments in the Six Senses Spa made our holiday unforgettable in Tea Factory. The Natural rock junior Suite in Earl's Regency made us book the same room on both our visits. The beautiful view of the misty mountains and river made you relax and enjoy the beauty of nature. Overall it was a great experience staying with Aitken Spence Hotels and value for what you pay and made us want to visit Sri Lanka again. I recommend any traveller to go through the Aitken Spence Hotels web page to know more details about Heritance Kandalama which I was unable to visit as many advise mean that you experience a uniqueness in this property.

I liked hotel very much. It is very clean, situated in a nice place, warm ocean, good meal, friendly staff (1$ makes unbelievable things :))) ) , I was staying here from the end of february till 12 march. Now its rainy time, so the best time to go here is december - february. Girls on the beach (those who sell different [--]) and beach boys at the begging annoyed quite much, but as your sunbake is becoming more dark - attention from the boys and girls on the beach normalizes. mainly people from poland, germany, england and local guests. Also there were periodically russians that are very energetic :) Almost all geuests are over the hill (over 40), so i was in trouble to find nice chicks (20+) to comunicate :))) Used the help of Kamal (tuk-tuk guy), very nice and friendly man!!! Reccomending him!!! So concluding - staying was very nice!

We absolutely love this hotel. The grounds are beautiful, it has amazing pools! The rooms are fab, the standard rooms are amazing and the deluxe rooms even better! We had our wedding here right on the beach. The hotel staff were fantastic and treated us like VIPs throughout. They are very attentive and helpful. The food is amazing and lots of choice. They have recently opened a spa there, which is an added bonus but I think it still needs some time to get going. Love this hotel so much and will go back everytime I return to Sri Lanka!

we were booked here for 6 nights after our round-the-island tour. This hotel was selected as it was the one being pushed by the major tour operator (to whom we have sent a full and damning report) and, at the time of booking the reports on this site were good, although these have now changed. To be fair, we WERE tired after travelling all day. Reception seemed ok until you raised your eyes sea-ward and saw the lager-swilling, chain-smoking and tattooed "guests" and the dirty looking swimming pool with broken sunbeds (covered with filthy mattresses) Need I go on? We checked out to the Taj Exotica which for a few pounds more per night was first class I should say that Heritance is about 20 minutes south of Bentota, so not exactly close to anything to allow you to escape

Good hotel with a great pool and also on the beach. Rooms are spacious and clean but a bit tired in places, the sunbed cushions have also seen better days. Service was very slow, when it happened at all, and therefore would not consider the hotel to be 5 star, more like 4. Food was average and again, you had to ask for things at least three times before you had a hope of getting them. People hang around the edge of the hotel on the beach trying to sell you anything they can and you need to pass them to get to the beach/sea each time, the beach and hotel also have a lot of stray dogs wandering around. A good stay as we were here for a wedding, but definitely not 5 star standard.

We stayed at the Heritance in February for one week for our wedding and my parents stayed there for a further week whilst we were on our honeymoon in the Maldives! I do not have one bad word to say about the Heritance - Ideally my rating would be 4.5 out of 5 but don't know how to do that!!!! From the moment we arrived we were made to feel truly special, welcome drink, cooling face-cloth, a flower necklace (as we were a 'wedding couple') and a chilled easy check-in. Our room was large and spacious with a glimpse of the sea and the 2nd pool and the bathroom was huge and the shower was good - much needed after the very long flight and 3.5 hour transfer!!!!! Towels in room changed twuice daily if you wanted and most evenings someone came round to the rooms with canapes - bliss! The staff make the hotel they really do - they are so warm, friendly and lovely and do everything they can to make you feel comfortable and relaxed - from the pool guys (my mums 'demands' as it were for sunbeds in a particular place, matresses and towels were met with smiles, jokes and laid out every morning for them - more than I'd have done LOL), to the bar staff (lovely) to the restaurant staff (just as lovely) to the absolutely fantastic wedding co-ordinator(s) - you really couldn't ask for more! Our wedding day with beach back drop was magical, the bestest day ever and went beyound my dreams for how fab and special they made it for us. From start to finish it was perfect, the ceremony was beautiful and the meal in the evening on the beach was gorgeous and the food 5* ala carte yum!!!! I really would recommend marrying there - it was amazing!!!!! Food at the Heritance is really good - it was a shame we were getting married and I had to be semi good as otherwise I think I would have let loose quite happily and out on loads haha! We were HB and didn't really need to have lunch, so didn't feel we had missed out too much but would recommend HB or FB as there is not many places to go outside the hotel for meals that are of a good standard and meals can be expensive if only BB. We just did one boat trip while were there which was part of our wedding package and I would reommend that thoroughly, had we been there for longer I would have loved to have done the overnight trip to the Elephant Orphanage and Kandy but we didn't have time. My parents did do trips out and would highly recommend the Turtle Hatchery over things like going to Galle for the day etc. The only thing negative I could say about Heritance is the sellers on the beach - they stand right outside the hotel beach front on the 'Government owned / public' bit of the beach constantly waving / calling to try and get your attention and you can't go onto the beach without them hassling you - which is a shame as the stretch of beach the Heritance is on is stunning (though the tide is way to rough to swim - which is another shame!!) BUT all this is out of the Heritance's control which is why only 4.5 out of 5 rather than 5 as I am being a bit mean and picky :-) They now have a spa and horse riding as extra activities - I used the spa and the girls are lovely but didn't try the horse riding but it looked fun and they let the horses graze at breakfast time and if you're sat outside they come to your table for a nose - which is really fun and lovely (if you like that sort of thing). We loved it there and will go back - other holiday makers there are regulars each year for anniversaries - so that says something :-) Will be adding pictures when can work out how to do it!!!!!

We stayed at the Heritance recently to celebrate our 10th wedding anniversary (we married there when it was the Triton hotel) and had a fantastic time. Our impressions of the hotel don't seem to quite tie in with other reviewers on this site! We booked everything independently and Sumaya who handled our reservation was very helpful, friendly, professional and efficient. Sadly the airport pick-up that we booked with them never materialised but we were easily able to find a great taxi-driver at the airport who charged much less than the hotel had quoted and although it is a long transfer the standard of driving was excellent (much better than we are used to at home!). The meet and greet at the hotel was very good; welcome drink on arrival and then shown to the restaurant for lunch. We booked on a FB basis so all our meals were taken in the Jute Restaurant and the food and service were always excellent; Sunhil who seemed to be serving us most of the time was great. Breakfast, lunch and dinner was always plentiful with enough variety to keep everyone happy and the standard of the meals was always excellent. Our room and the hotel in general was spotlessly clean and all of the staff very helpful and polite. The beach is fantastic although sadly the sea was always too rough to swim in but the pools more than make up for that. The wooden sun-beds do exactly what they're meant to ... give you somewhere with a fantastic view to relax and watch the amazing sunsets. Yes, there are a lot of hawkers on the beach and they can be a pain but if you're firm and polite with them then they will back off and they're only trying to earn a few rupees anyway. As for the entertainment; well, do you really need it? You have a fantastic place in which to relax and do nothing - it's entertainment enough to watch the sunrise and sunset and listen to the waves. Certainly as a place to unwind the hotel is great and its very easy to simply get a tuk-tuk from outside the hotel and just go off and explore. Further afield there is much to see ... Sigiriya, Kandy etc., and nearby the Kosgoda Turtle Hatchery is definately worth a visit. All in all if you want a relaxing time with good service, great food and lovely scenery - it makes a great place for a holiday.

We stayed at the Heritance Ahungalla over Christmas and New Year 2008. Firstly when you reach Sri Lanka you are greated by a driver to take you the 3 hours down to the hotel, i would suggest closing your eyes and trying to forget that you are most likely to be on the wrong side of the road, doing a multiple overtaking manouver. If you can get your head around the driving style then you will be able to enjoy the view out of the window to entertain your journey. Once we arrived we were greated by very friendly staff who took us to the bar for a well desreved refreshment. We enquired about upgrading our rooms before our bags were taken to the allocated ones, and they were more than happy to show us what they had available. I would advise that you do this and see more than one because as we found out, some that say they are a sea view have huge trees right infront of the balcony, hence no view. We found a lovely room over looking the main infinity pool and sea. I would say that after my husband viewed a couple of upgrade rooms, its not worth the money, unless your planning on being in your room for most of your holiday! We found that the restaurants are not very varied in choice and not at all to the standard that we would expect, so after a couple of days we were desperate to get out of the hotel and find somewhere else to eat. We ended up in Bentota which is half an hour away by car and Hickadua which is also half an hour away, 1 hour round trip at the closest to eat outside of the hotel was not ideal! so only did a couple of times. This is something to bear in mind also when you stay here, if you are told a trip/meal/room service etc will be a certain amount of time, be sure to add on at LEAST an hour to journeys and about half an hour for the rest. This became abit of an issue in regards to food and drinks for us especially on occasions when the food was of poor standard when it did finally arrive. We decided not to stay for the galla dinner on New Years Eve so we booked a trip to Uda Walawe National Park for an overnight stay which we booked independantly with eco tours. The journey there we were told would take three hours, five hours later we finally arrived!! We were not dissapointed though, well worth a trip if you can stomach the journey. The staff were absolutely fantastic, full of information on the wildlife, and couldnt do enough for us back at camp. They even put up balloons and made us a cake for New Years Eve dinner under the stars! We were dissapointed with the standard of cleanliness around temples and the big buhdda, they could do alot more to improve the rubbish everywhere really (including the world heritage site in Galle!) We did take into account that the tsunami hit hard on the south east coast of Sri Lanka, and that locals are trying their hardest to get back on their feet, but even a member of staff at the hotel admitted that there is one price for locals, and a much higher price for tourist, which we were more than aware of and didnt appreciate. The Hotel was very clean over all and the staff very friendly. If you dont like being hassled whilst sun bathing then try and stay back from the beach as the beach sellers are very persistant and will not take no for an answer, we found that if you tell them you are leaving the next day they back off abit. I would say that if we travelled to Sri Lanka again then we would most likely stay at this hotel again, but not for our whole stay as it would be better to travel around the island to get the most of your stay there.

Kuoni rate this hotel as 4.5 stars...uhhhmm im not convinced.. First impressions are good as it has a stunning entrance, palm trees, flood lit pond and a huge lobby. Walking through the lobby you are presented with the main pool and wooden boat, stunning at sunset. Rooms: The couple we travelled with got a great room overlooking the pool and beach, we were given a dark corner terrace room overlooking a tree (I would recommend requesting a sea facing room if possible), we were not best pleased so ended up looking at some other rooms until we found one that warranted the sea view we were after. Admittedly they did their best to please. The rooms are nice, very comfortable with a tasteful Indonesian/Asian theme, air con, rain shower, some English TV Channels. Food: I would say average, certainly not 4/5 star. A lot of luke warm food served and as mentioned in other posts food is at 4/5 star prices. Breakfast was a good spread buffet but the other restaurants in resort became painful by the end of the holiday due to poor food and service. Service: I forget exactly how many times we asked twice/three times for our food. One â€˜in room dining experienceâ€™ left us with a beef burger without beef in it? This isnâ€™t aimed at all of the staff, some of them are exceptional (eg: Rukmal the Bar Captain and the drinks guys) but generally within the restaurants the pace is slow and not very alert. On our last day 1 waiter was serving the entire pool area and yet 6 staff were behind the reception desk doing what exactly!?! I also felt, as have others that they were constantly after a tip (this is generally the rule of thumb in and out of the hotel) Entertainment: Most nights was Piano/live music, pretty bland and not much to do with Sri Lanka. Our last night was a Sri Lankan theme night which was enjoyable with Sinhalese dancers, why they don't do more of this I don't know. The Hotel: Im sure after its refurbishment it looked fantastic but It looks tired in places, the eves of the main building look tired and need a paint, the grounds are ok, sports facilities are good, tennis, ping pong, badmington, gym, beach volley ball, water aerobics etc. The wooden sun-beds are past it and the cushions are all stained and well past there sell by date. The Beach: Fantastic beach, silky sand and miles long, the sea, warm and like a big wave machine, had a lot of fun in it, the only negative is the beach hawkers, consistently pestering you, even on our last day, last sunset, cocktail on the beach, it would appear to be a general problem in Sri Lanka though. Out & About. Sri Lanka is a huge country and the infrastructure is still pretty basic, the journey down from the airport with a psychotic driver took 3.5 hours, the roads are a bumpy roller coaster ride and not for the fain hearted so be prepared!. There isnâ€™t much outside the hotel, just the busy road and the odd shop. 5 minutes up the road is the Kosgoda Turtle Sanctuary, definitely worth the visit as the guy is doing an amazing job with the â€˜little shelled fellasâ€™, and is slowly rebuilding the sanctuary and his home after the devastating Tsunami. 20 minutes away is Bentota, we visited the Mask (museum/shop/workshop) great to see first hand the stunning wood work first hand, also the Bentota Herb Garden was pretty interesting. Down towards Galle we visited Balapitiya for the river safari, well worth a trip, huge water monitor lizards and stunning scenery, make sure you see the Monastery on the River Safari, very humbling meeting the child monks there. Galle was disappointing; the fort was covered in rubbish and didnâ€™t look much like a World Heritage Site to me. Also Hikkaduwa Coral Garden is a miss, most of the coral is dead. The highlight for us was the safari at Uda Walawe National Park (5hr journey), we stayed in the Mahoora luxury campsite 16km into the reserve on new Years Eve, singing Sinhalese songs with the staff at midnight really was something special. Expect to see lots of Elephants (some 400 within the reserve), a wealth of birds, water buffalo, crocs, monkeys, deer, reptiles etc etcâ€¦.. To sum up the Heritance Ahungalla. Stunning sunsets, great pools and cocktails (Rukmal!) but unfortunately its trying too hard to be something thatâ€™s its not, and that s 4 1/2 star hotel..

I couldn't agree more with the comments below. We stayed there from 26th December until after New Year. Had we been able to get a refund we would have moved out on day 1! Firstly, despite what their website says, all rooms do NOT have a sea view. We were given a room overlooking the tennis courts. After a huge discussion, they said that we could move to a lower category room - where a seaview was availabile - BUT they wouldn't refund us the Â£450 difference. After I pointed out that they were falsely advertising, the local agent out there agreed to pay for us to upgrade us to a luxury suite - however, the hotel really should have picked up this cost as their website was giving incorrect information! The suite was ok - but not worth the money they charge. Again, their website states luxury goods and free sparkling wine, fruit etc. None of those things materialised! The shower gel was provided in glass bottles which took forever to let the gel out. There was no conditioner, no bubble bath and the cotton buds were only supplied on the first day - all basic things for a 5 star hotel! The lighting is also totally illogical as the person states below. It's certainly not a luxury 5 star property. There's water aerobics in the pool every day - with loud techno music blaring out of the speakers. They had Karaoke in one bar and a very naff electronic keyboard player belting out songs like "lady in red" in the other. Not exclusive property that it claims to be! The sun loungers had dirty cushions - which didn't even cover the whole of the lounger - and there weren't enough for the number of guests. You were also shouted at by the hawkers from the beach - which really shouldn't happen at this type of property (I've stayed at lots in Sri Lanka and nowhere else is like that!) Finally, the food. It was very uninspiring for the cost. The upper restaurant was not open the whole time we were there - so the only a la carte menu available was from the coffee shop. I think it's an absolute disgrace to charge the money they do - I was incredibly misled and I too will be lodging a formal complaint. The only saving grace was the location - but frankly - there are lots of hotels in Sri Lanka with just as nice locations - minus the hawkers and at a much cheaper cost!
Wonderful looking hotel, good location, nice beach, beautiful pool, good standard of room. Staff aren't the best - bit slow and forgetful but not rude.

We stayed at this place for 4 days 3 nights - US$1,100, included a lame New Year buffet and "celebration" (US$125 per person) This hotel bore no resemblance with its sister hotel in the same group Heritance Kandalama (where we stayed over Christmas and which was impressive). The architectual and design elememts that make Heritance Kandalama very special are total lacking in the Heritance Alungalla. The level of service could not compared. The attitude of staff generally was insincere and gear towards tips rather than service. We also had 2 experiences of male staff members making inappropriate comments to the females in our group. The food was uninspiring at best and unhygenically prepared at worst (one of our party and a known other guest were both made ill by poor food preparation.) When the issue was raised on our departure with the most senior staff member made available (only a room division manager), no responsiblity was taken nor apology offered and the stock response was that the guest had not until then made a formal complaint (despite the matter being known to reception and housekeeping staff) and the guest was blamed for not having asked for a hotel doctor at the time. The room we had was an attempt maximizing a corner area and was at first glance impressive. However, not all the electrics were wired up and the basic layout of the location of the light switches was poor (you have to get out of bed to turn off the bed side light). And one of the toilet in the suite smelt which affected our enjoyment of the suite. We couldn't use the sitting area of the suite. To cap it all, having paid US$100 for a vehicle to take us to the airport, the hotel provided a desperately underpower, mini people mover which had no safety belts for passengers (an essential requirement for Sri Lankan roads). Compared to the rest of our experience of accommodation in Sri Lanka, Heritance Alungalla was over-priced and poor value. It is definitely not 5 star accommodation as it claims to be. It just seems to be a money making "machine". The main positive point about this hotel is the beach which is beautiful like the rest of the West coast of Sri Lanka (you do have to however put up with beach touts). We will be lodging a formal complaint to the hotel but given their initial response we do not expect any joy.

I have been at Heritance a few times before and simply love this place. It has got better since the Tsunami and the hotel was refurbished. It is a must stay if you are on a holiday in Sri Lanka. Staff are very friendly and the food fantastic!!! The hotel is great to just relax or there are things around the town to see, Galle is not too far away for a day trip. I will be looking forward to my next stay at this hotel!

We've just returned from our honeymoon - a week in the Maldives(paradise) followed by a week in Sri Lanka staying in the Heritance Ahungalla. The hotel is beautiful just like any hotel in a major city let it be London, Dublin or New York so if its traditional Sri Lankan style your looking for than its not for you. Our room was looking out onto the ocean however the water was unfortunately too rough for swimming. There wasn't a soul on the beach for the entire duration of our trip apart from the usual hawkers who camp out on the beach for the day in the hope of selling the odd sarong or two. The food was nice but became extremely repetitive when your there for 6 days, bearing in mind there's nothing outside the hotel so no chance of eating anywhere else. If you like a drink and a bit of a buzz at nite then this is also not the hotel for you, the bars have no atmosphere.Your not encouraged to go out of the hotel however saying that there's nothing to go out for in the line of entertainment, shopping or eating just a little shop across the road which sells water and snacks which may come in handy as hotels prices are the same if not even more expenive than home. Once you walk out of the hotel you'll be surrounded by hawkers trying to sell you tours which can be annoying as they're fairly persistent. We went on a local tour by tuk tuk with Raji who camps out outside the hotel or beach, his English is perfect which helps. This was quite enjoyable apart from being brought to two different shops trying to get us to buy stuff, this is standard procedure if u take a tuk tuk anyway. We did the nearby river safari which we booked through our travel rep. This would be very managable and much cheaper to do by travelling by tuk tuk and hopping on a boat when you get there, just a few mins down the road. We also went to a national park spotting elephants, about 9 hrs in a car but enjoyable all the same.All of the staff in the hotel were outstanding very friendly and pleasant. Sri Lanka is really just a country for touring around, the ideal would be 4 or 5 days seeing the sights staying in a different hotel ever nite. As part of a tour I would defintely recommend a nite or two in this hotel but def no longer.

Just got back from the Heritance and had a marvellous time there.It is beautifully designed,with two infinity pools leading your eye out to the sea.Our room had a great sea view and was very well furnished.Beds were comfy and the bathroom was great-I want a wet room like theirs!!!Premiership matches on the box and two english speaking movie channels. The food was very good and i found myself eating curry three times a day!!i also brought a hopper pan back with me to have egg-hoppers for beakfast.However we were a little disappointed with the fine dining restaurant.The prices are the same as back home, and they had very pretty food on the plate, but it needs Gordon Ramsey to go in and make it less fussy and more tasty.With such good seafood(the tuna is the best!) i would have liked to have seen a japanese restaurant or something similar.The 'mustard' coffe shop was more to our liking-less pretentious and good food,and of course you can always find something nice in the buffet restaurant. Service is very good,if a little too much! Sri Lanka is a paradise for wildlife and the hotel has in it's grounds; egrets,bee-eaters,squirrels,a small monitor lizard,gecko's and on an evening a large bat which we named 'Nora' (Batty!) which swooped around the pool bar while we were sipping pre dinner Martini's! We went on a river cruise through the mangroves which was excellent and a trip to Sinharaja Rainforest ,which is a must for bird watchers.Our driver Erish was the best.He took us around the village he grew up in and to meet some of his family,and releasing baby turtles into the sea at Kosgoda was very satisfying. Don't let tales of war in the north put you off going,you are not affected in the least.Soldiers with guns are at a lot of check points near Colombo,but there are thousands of Tamils and Sinhalese living in perfect harmony,it is lot more safe than Northern Ireland ever was.Just keep away from the north and north east to be on the safe side. They have recovered physically very well from the Tsunami,but anyone you talk to has lost loved ones(60,000 people)There won't be another one for hundreds of years,so don't let that put you off either! The Hotel is excellent and Sri Lanka is a lush,wildlife filled paradise,with sun and picture postcard beaches.It reminded me of a cross between Thailand(with Buddhist temples all over) and the nicer parts of south goa,give it a try.We'll definitely go back.

We stayed at the Heritance for two nights at the end of the Kuoni Ceylon South Tour before we flew to the Maldives. The hotel was absolute heaven. We were stunned by the beautiful entrance when we arrived and the rest of our group were very jealous and were tempted to sneak off the bus too! The room was beautiful with an excellent view. The hotel was immaculate, the staff were wonderful, the food was delicious. The only thing that upset us was that the hotel was so quiet. Obviously it was nice and relaxing from our point of view. We were always the only people in the pool and the gym â€“ we felt like celebrities who had hired the whole hotel to ourselves. However the downside of this was that the wonderful staff must make far less in tips when there are so few guests staying. We have sent a letter to Kuoni urging them to make this hotel the standard hotel for the end of the Ceylon South Tour as it was simply the perfect end to our tour. We were sad that we couldn't stay longer.

I stayed here with my wife for 6 days in June and it really is a fantastic place. The hotel is exceptionally presented, the room we had immaculate, with a stunning sea view. The staff there deserve high praise for making this place what it is, they really know how to look after you and are some of the friendliest people Iâ€™ve ever met. Everyone always had a smile and seemed genuinely interested in helping or just making conversation (without being intrusive) whatever time of the day! Their knowledge of football was limited though as they only seem to have heard of David Beckham!! â€“ Cricket is what matters here! The pools were excellent, large and clean & the food in the restaurants (Jute & Mustard) outstanding. The meals were great value (we stayed on B&B basis) with the evening meals costing on average about Â£35 for both of us (3 courses) including a bottle of wine. (The wine is the same price as UK restaurants) The evenings that we ate in the main restaurant (Jute) this was always buffet with a theme (Chinese, BBQ etc) but there were always other options available. My wife described the curries as the â€˜best sheâ€™d ever eatenâ€™ The hotel is a little isolated but set in beautiful grounds and right on a great stretch of beach â€“ unfortunately due to the time of year the sea was too rough for swimming. I didnâ€™t really get the impression though that this was a â€˜beach resortâ€™ as all the guests stayed by the pools, this maybe however due to the time of year I visited (monsoon season) but the weather was fantastic and extremely hot - also the beaches are public so although they are only trying to make a living you are targeted by the â€˜beach hawkersâ€™ as soon as they spot you on the sand! We did a day trip to Galle, incorporating a visit to a turtle hatchery, a river boat safari, mask museum & lunch at a great seafood restaurant. On our check out morning we left for a mini tour to Kandy, visiting the Elephant Orphanage at Pinnawala, the Millennium Elephant Foundation (where as well as learning about the elephants you can ride and feed them â€“ this was a fantastic experience and in my opinion much better than the Orphanage, where the workers main interest seems to be getting as many tips out of you for photoâ€™s as possible!) a tea factory, a herb garden, the Botanical Gardens & the Temple of the Tooth. There is some stunning scenery & views in Kandy and none more so than from the cliff side restaurant we stopped at for lunch, which offered great views for miles across the City. We arranged all our excursions & Airport transfers through Rammuni Tours, (Mr Silva) which were great value and Iâ€™d highly recommend to any of my family and friends travelling to Sri Lanka (Iâ€™m happy to pass on his contact details to anyone who wants them) Sri Lanka really is a country to be visited & the Heritance Ahungalla is definitely a great place to stay. We are hoping to return some time in the near future and would with out a doubt stay here again.
Great for rest. Beautiful beach, with lots of waves. The fauna in the hotel was great: squirrels, monkeys, iguanas... all friendly. The staff was very nice, especially the animator and the gim guy.

we travelled here with our two sons, 13 and 16, in 2001, as a two centre with the maldives, this was our first stop. firstly sri lankan airlines was the best airline we had ever travelled on, even better than virgin. the hotel then was called the triton, which we was upgraded from after we complained, before we travelled, as our original hotel, the swanee, was slated in a telly programme. the hotel was first rate.it's own elephant, numerous weddings going on. beautiful food, even curry for breakfast, if you wished ! ice carving and fruit carving to watch. little chipmunks running all over the place, don't touch them though. a bloke rescued one from the swimming pool, got bit, and was taken to hospital for a rabies jab. sea rough, just paddle and jump the waves. swimming pools good. would watch a large monitor lizard some days, it would wander and then start digging, sadly eating turtle eggs, it was digging up, but hey, that's nature.lots of other little lizards around. and many insects, didn't see any spiders though. took a taxi, they are friendly and cheap, please give them a tip, they work for very low wages, especially the staff at the hotel, my husband gave a bloke that was cleaning up round the pool, a few dollars and he said it was more than he earned in a week ! we went to a turtle farm, worth going, and unawatuna beach, as we were told it may be calmer there, it was a little.we wished we had went to the elephant orphanage, but it was so hot. i know the hotel now is under another name, i hope the people here weren't too badly affected by the tsunami, i know it hit here. did the elephant survive ?i know when we heard of the disaster, our first thoughts were for a family, which sold tablecloths on the beach, and had a little place right up on the right hand side of the beach. they lived here. i still think of them, when i lay down my elephant cloth on my dining table.

Booked this along with a 5 day stay in Dubai for our Honeymoon last October. Booked through Key2Holidays (also very good!!). The hotel was fantastic, we splashed out and booked one of the top suites - named the 'Cliff Richard' suite and it was amazing (marred by a slight smell of drains in the bathroom - but this was fixed within 30 minutes of raising the concern.
